body.p:
my dear Friend, i have left you to find out by the Northern Star, where i have been the last fortnight, increasing in usefulness, though not in wealth. i was able out of Bradford and Leeds receipts to send Mrs Carlile a five pound note, and ever since that i have not recovered myself so as to have a pound to spare. the Chartists and Socialists studiously unite against me. this evening in Bolton, there is a special meeting of Chartists called in the open air to keep them away from hearing me in the theatre. this is avowed. last night, i opposed the views of O Brien, or presented better principles rather, in Batty's Circus. O Brien is but a miserable orator with a miserable political subject. he fell much below my expectations. i began with an angry audience but mastered their feelings and commanded their respect. O Brien revenged himself by addressing Paine, not much to the taste of his audience. i have challenged him to further discussion, which i fear he will not accept. i have assured myself that he is a mere blarneying Irishman of the O Connel [sic] stamp. on monday night i had an audience below expences in the Carpenter's Hall. on sunday, a very large and well [[2]] behaved audience in Bolton Market Square. on friday last a large audience in Rochdale Church Yard [.] monday, wednesday and thursday in Halifax â€“ to return there next sunday. on sunday the 7th i addressed 5000 people in Leeds and Dewsbury. the former sunday in Bradford presented me with an audience of upwards of two thousand. i must be doing good ; for new as is my subject, it delights the audiences. one of the best discussions i have had with Jones was in Leeds before a large audience. there was another in Bradford of the same kind. the Leeds Times will have told you something of this. i do not see the day yet when i can return to London, as i am still wanting and looking for money. to morrow i am to be in Huddersfield, where they are building a fine Social Hall. i may have to visit Preston before i return to Sheffield ; but for this, i wait a letter from Gloucestershire . i did not see and could not hear of Mr Appleton of Leeds. [[3]] i have well agitated every town i have visited since i left Sheffield, and i do not despair of putting myself at the head of a respectable popularity when the Suckbull [Tuckbull? something - bull anyway] of Chartism and Socialism has subsided ; to which i allow another twelve months. six months will settle Chartism. i could not find at the Northern Star Office a copy of O Brien's challenge. you may keep mine. he is no fire eater in oratory but a mere vain, conceited creature. i expect from Wheeler and his party of mad caps here something of the same game as had been going on in Birmingham. that is a specimen of the beginning! i am about to print a twopenny address to the Chartists, to seek to stay their present extravagance. love to your family and respectfully yours R. carlile
you would have been proud of me before O Brien last night.
[[4]] [i sp]ent my last shilling this morning, so i leave you [only?] this letter.
